oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Unidentified young woman and infant with a large quilt

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Women; Infants; Quilts
Quilts; Women; Infants; Mothers
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Unidentified young woman holding an infant and standing in front of a large hanging quilt. The quilt is a Crazy quilt pattern.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Edna Mays Miracle Liming Family Photographs, ca. 1880s-1920s
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Japanese style of asymmetrical art was exhibited during the Philadelphia Centennial Exposition of 1876. The “Crazy” quilt pattern cropped up during the Victorian period as a way for women to include the Japanese design they had seen in their quilts. Most Crazy quilts were made with silk, satin, or velvet as opposed to cotton and were only used as display quilts. Crazy quilts can be identified by their uneven fabric blocks and the fine ornamental embroidery stitches on their tops. Popular decorative motifs on these quilts included fans, animals, and insects. Spiders and webs can often be seen on Crazy quilts as they were thought to bring good luck to the quiltmaker.
